messageBody:
Kent Beck wrote:

> Jason,
>
> Thank you for the clear example. It seems to me that you can do this
> kind of
> validation in a @BeforeClass in JUnit 4. Would that solve your problem?

Not so easily in this case. This is a validation that is run before any
other test in the AllTests suite, if it fails no other test is run. You
get a single failure, fix the web.xml file and then run again. In order
to get this same behavior in JUnit4 I would have to duplicate the
@BeforeClass and @AfterClass annotations into every TestCase.
Annotations in this sense are really starting to sound like Advices in
the AOP world.

Similarly, we have functional tests that use a type of validation like
the one I mentioned before that connect to a third party WebService and
grab its WSDL (Salesforce.com). The validation checks the WSDL in the
service against the WSDL we have saved locally. If they don't match we
know that we need to regenerate classes from the WSDL. Since the
objects we are currently working with are now "out of date" running the
tests don't make too much sense, so we throw a failure and refuse to run
any other tests. The developer at that point copies the new WSDL to
his/her local directory, regenerates classes, and runs tests again.
This is especially important at check-in time so that we know that the
HEAD of our CVS branch is generally in line with the WebService --
allowing us to make a build out of HEAD at any time.

As I said earlier the @BeforeClass and @AfterClass are too limited in
their scope to allow for such validations. Please correct me if I am wrong.

--
Jason Rogers
